Award.AwardTitle: Assessing population size and structure of the longfin smelt (Spirinchus thaleichthys) in the Nooksack River

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will increase the body of knowledge on the population dynamics of longfin smelt (Spirinchus thaleichthys), an important species of forage fish that is not protected nor its catch monitored.

Northwest Indian College (NWIC) will conduct a study that aims to (1) determine temporal genetic structure of the Nooksack River longfin smelt population; (2) determine the existence of a genetic bottleneck; (3) estimate the effective population size; and (4) consider the conservation implications of these findings. At the local level, the data from this study will aid management decisions by both state and tribal agencies. At the national level, the genetic information acquired in this study will add to the overall knowledge of distinct population segments of longfin smelt. These data will aid multiple agencies that cross international and state lines in assessing other populations of longfin smelt and whether they constitute distinct population segments. In addition, the information collected during this study will provide baseline data for the effective population size of the Nooksack River longfin smelt population. These data can be used to assess future trends in population size in the light of changing river conditions, development of or near the Nooksack River riparian habitat, and in the face of climate change and ocean acidification. And lastly, the information gained from this study will add to the limited understanding of the basic biology of the longfin smelt by making the data available to other researchers, management agencies, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Longfin Smelt (Spirinchus thaleichthys) of the Nooksack River in Bellingham, Washington, are culturally-important to the Lummi People and are part of their traditional subsistence diet. While no tribal or non-tribal governmental agencies are monitoring the population, elders from the Lummi community were the first to point out that the Nooksack population has been declining: the spawning runs used to be much longer (greater than two weeks by some accounts), the fish larger in size, and the population used to include many more individuals. A major outcome of this study was to determine whether any genetic structure existed within the population, especially between even and odd year runs, in order to better understand the population and provide information for management agencies. In addition, another major objective of this study was to create a genomics laboratory at the Salish Sea Research Center at Northwest Indian College, increasing the capacity of the college to do genomics research. The genomics research on the Longfin Smelt also included positions for summer student internships, so that students in the Native Environmental Science Program at Northwest Indian College would be able to gain hands-on research experience in a genomics laboratory. The last major objective of this study was to design a culturally-relevant course on introductory genetics and evolution to be implemented during the 2016–2017 and 2017–2018 academic years, as NWIC had no course offerings for those subject areas.

By the end of summer quarter 2016, a state-of-the-art genomics laboratory, fully capable of producing libraries for next-generation sequencing, was added to the Salish Sea Research Center (SSRC) on the Lummi campus of Northwest Indian College. Six student interns have taken part in the research project on the Longfin Smelt, with some of those students deciding to pursue genomics research as part of their long-term career goals. The students were also supported to present their internship research at both local and national conferences and symposiums. BIOL 344—Introduction to Genetics and Evolution, was added to the NWIC course catalog and taught in a face-to-face modality in the 2016–2017 and 2017–2018 academic years. This course includes topics related to blood quantum, the lactase persistence gene, conservation genetics, and the ethics of genetics research in tribal communities. For the 2018–2019 academic year, the course was moved online to reach students from satellite campuses and remote students without access to an NWIC campus. The course is considered an elective at NWIC and has attracted 13 students over the granting period.

The population study was conducted over the 2016–2017 spawning seasons for Longfin Smelt that return to the Nooksack River in Bellingham, Washington, in conjunction with staff at Lummi Natural Resources. The Longfin Smelt belong to the Family Osmeridae (Order Osmeriformes) and are part of the group of forage fishes that inhabit the open oceans and inland seas from Prince William Sound, Alaska to San Francisco Bay, California. The southern-most population in San Francisco Bay, California, has declined dramatically and is listed as Threatened under the California Endangered Species Act. The Longfin Smelt of the Nooksack River are known locally as “Hooligans”; they return each Fall and have been harvested by the Lummi People using dip nets since time immemorial. While largely considered a failed fishery by most fishermen dip netting for Hooligans during the 2017 spawning run, the genomics study was still able to be completed in 2018 with 91 individuals genotyped—54 from 2016 and 37 from 2017. The outcomes from this study are being discussed with staff at Lummi Natural Resources to determine appropriate community reporting and management action.

This project was designed with the intention of bringing culturally-relevant genomics research to Northwest Indian College and the Lummi community. The project was largely successful, and has led to further requests from Lummi Natural Resources for genomics projects that will help the agency monitor and better manage marine species that are culturally important to the Lummi People.
